Background.text: This uninhabited, volcanic, Antarctic island is almost entirely covered by glaciers and is the most remote island on Earth, making it difficult to approach. It was discovered in 1739 by the French naval officer after whom the island was named. No claim was made until 1825, when the British flag was raised. In 1928, the UK waived its claim in favor of Norway, which had occupied the island the previous year. In 1971, Norway designated Bouvet Island and the adjacent territorial waters a nature reserve. Since 1977, Norway has run an automated meteorological station and studied foraging strategies and distribution of fur seals and penguins on the island.

Location.text: island in the South Atlantic Ocean, southwest of the Cape of Good Hope (South Africa)

Area - comparative.text: about 0.3 times the size of Washington, DC

Geography - note.text: covered by glacial ice; declared a nature reserve by Norway

Dependency status.text: territory of Norway; administered by the Polar Department of the Ministry of Justice and Oslo Police

Legal system.text: the laws of Norway, where applicable, apply

Flag description.text: the flag of Norway is used

Economy - overview.text: no economic activity; declared a nature reserve

Military - note.text: defense is the responsibility of Norway
